label: Alexandria Digital Library Feature Type Thesaurus

children.label: cadastral areas
children.definition: Areas for which there exist public records, surveys, or maps of the value, extent, and ownership of land as a basis of taxation. [American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: exclusive economic zones
children.definition: Offshore areas whose extent is governed by the UN convention on Law of the Sea, where some economic activities are restricted. Extends generally 200 nautical miles from national coastlines.

children.label: countries
children.definition: Territory occupied by a large group of people organized under a single, usually independent government, and recognized as a country internationally. [Adapted from American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: countries, 1st order divisions
children.definition: First-order divisions of a nation. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: countries, 2nd order divisions
children.definition: Second-order divisions of a nation such as parishes, boroughs, counties, municipios, or judicial divisions, and independent cities such as those in Maryland, Missouri, Nevada, and Virginia. [Adapted from USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: countries, 3rd order divisions
children.definition: Minor civil units. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: countries, 4th order divisions
children.definition: Minor civil units. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: populated places
children.definition: Places or areas with clustered or scattered buildings and a permanent human population. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: cities
children.definition: Incorporated populated places. [Adapted from USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: capitals
children.definition: Towns or cities that are the official seats of government in a political entity, such as a state or nation. [American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: postal areas
children.definition: Designated zones of a country for efficient sorting and delivery of mail.

children.label: school districts
children.definition: Geographic districts, the public schools of which are administered together. [American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: Metropolitan Statistical Areas
children.definition: Defined urbanized areas for statistical purposes meeting requirements of the Census Bureau. [Adapted from <http://www.census.gov/population/www/estimates/aboutmetro.html>]

children.label: census areas
children.definition: Defined areas in which an official, usually periodic enumeration of a population is carried out, often including the collection of related demographic information. [Adapted from American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: tribal areas
children.definition: Areas reserved for indigenous inhabitants.

children.label: hydrographic features
children.definition: For natural bodies of water. For constructed waterways, reservoirs, and such, use 'hydrographic structures'.

children.label: aquifers
children.definition: Bodies of rock that contain sufficient saturated permeable material to conduct ground water and to yield significant quantities of water to  wells and springs. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: bays
children.definition: Indentations of a coastline or shoreline enclosing a part of a body of water; bodies of water partly surrounded by land. [USGS GNIS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: fjords
children.definition: Long narrow  glacially-eroded inlets of the sea, U-shaped and steep-walled, generally several hundred meters deep, between high rocky cliffs or slopes along a mountainous coast. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: channels
children.definition: (a) Relatively narrow seas or stretches of water between two close landmasses and connecting two larger bodies of water; (b) Deeper parts of a moving body of water (as bays, estuaries, or straits) through which the main current flows or which affords the best passage through an area otherwise too shallow to navigate. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: drainage basins
children.definition: Regions or areas bounded by drainage divides and occupied by drainage systems; specifically the tract of country that gathers water originating as precipitation and contributes it to a particular stream channel or system of channels, or to a lake, reservoir, or other body of water. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: estuaries
children.definition: Regions of interaction between rivers and near-shore ocean waters, where tidal action and river flow mix fresh and salt water. These brackish water ecosystems shelter and feed marine life, birds, and wildlife.. [EPA Terms of Environment < http://www.epa.gov/OCEPAterms/>]

children.label: floodplains
children.definition: Flat or nearly flat land along a river or stream or in a tidal area that is covered by water during a flood. [EPA Terms of Environment <http://www.epa.gov/OCEPAterms/>]

children.label: gulfs
children.definition: Largest of various forms of inlets of the sea; usually larger, more enclosed, and more deeply indented than bays. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: guts
children.definition: Relatively small coastal waterways connecting larger bodies of water or other waterways. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: ice masses
children.definition: Fields of ice, formed in regions of perennial frost. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: glacier features
children.definition: Bodies or streams of ice moving outward and downslope from an area of accumulation; areas of relatively permanent snow or ice on the top or side of a mountain or mountainous area. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: lakes
children.definition: Natural inland bodies of standing water, generally of appreciable size, occupying a depression in the Earth's surface. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: seas
children.definition: Large bodies of salt water. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: oceans
children.definition: Continuous salt-water bodies that surround the continents and fill the Earth's great depressions. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: ocean currents
children.definition: Broadly, currents in the ocean - tidal or nontidal, permanent or seasonal, horizontal or vertical - characterized by regularity, either as a continuous streams flowing along a definable path, or less commonly of a cyclic nature. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: ocean regions
children.definition: Use for sub-regions of oceans and seas.

children.label: streams
children.definition: Linear bodies of water flowing on the Earth's surface. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: rivers
children.definition: Natural freshwater surface streams of considerable volume and a permanent or seasonal flow, moving in a definite channel toward a sea, lake, or another river; any large streams, or ones larger than brooks or creeks, such as the trunk stream and larger branches of a drainage system.  [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: bends (river)
children.definition: Curves in the course of a stream and (or) the land within the curve; curves in a linear body of water. [USGS GNIS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: rapids
children.definition: Fast-flowing sections of a stream, often shallow and with exposed rock or boulders. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: waterfalls
children.definition: Perpendicular or very steep falls of water in the course of a stream. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: springs (hydrographic)
children.definition: Places where underground water flows naturally to the surface of the Earth. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: thermal features
children.definition: Holes in the Earth's crust from which hot water and steam (geysers), and gases and vapors (fumaroles) are emitted. [Adapted from USGS Circ 1048 and Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: land parcels
children.definition: Tracts or plots of the Earth's surface distinguishable by ownership. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: agricultural sites
children.definition: Use for locations and facilities named for their agricultural purposes of raising crops and livestock.

children.label: buildings
children.definition: Permanent constructions that are roofed and usually walled. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: capitol buildings
children.definition: Buildings in which governmental legislatures meet. [Adapted from American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: commercial sites
children.definition: Structures or groups of structures used for the sale of products and services. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: industrial sites
children.definition: Groups of associated structures functioning as a unit used for refining a material or manufacturing a product. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: power generation sites
children.definition: Groups of associated structures functioning as a unit used for generating electricity. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: court houses
children.definition: Buildings housing judicial courts, or the offices of a county governments. [American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: institutional sites
children.definition: Groups of buildings or associated structures functioning as a unit used predominantly for educational. correctional, governmental, medical, or religious purposes. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: correctional facilities
children.definition: Buildings and installations for the treatment of offenders (through a system of penal incarceration, rehabilitation, probation, and parole). [Adapted from American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: educational facilities
children.definition: Buildings or groups of buildings used as institutions for study, teaching, and learning. [USGS GNIS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: religious facilities
children.definition: Places built for the observance of faith and the pursuit of a religious life.

children.label: museum buildings
children.definition: Buildings where the acquisition, conservation, study, exhibition, and educational interpretation of objects having scientific, historical, or artistic value takes place.  [Adapted from American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: post office buildings
children.definition: Buildings where mail is received, sorted, and delivered, and where stamps and other postal materials are sold. [American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: housing areas
children.definition: Groups of buildings and neighborhoods in which people live.

children.label: cemeteries
children.definition: Areas of land for burying the dead with two or more graves. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: disposal sites
children.definition: Areas where refuse is dumped. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: firebreaks
children.definition: Areas cleared of vegetation for the purpose of impeding the progress of a grass or forest fire. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: fisheries
children.definition: Pools of water and related structures used for spawning and growing of fish (that are subsequently used to stock lakes and streams). [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: fortifications
children.definition: General term for any works made to oppose a small number of troops against a greater. [Getty Art & Architecture Thesaurus]

children.label: archaeological sites
children.definition: Areas of historical significance containing the deteriorated remains of a structure(s) or where past human life and activities are under study. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: hydrographic structures
children.definition: For constructed bodies of water. For natural water bodies, use 'hydrographic features'.

children.label: breakwaters
children.definition: Structures built to break the force of waves or to restrain or direct current so as to protect a breach, harbor, or other waterfront facility. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: canals
children.definition: Artificial waterways with no flow or a controlled flow used for navigation (canal), or for draining or irrigating land (ditch). [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: dam sites
children.definition: Areas including a dam and associated structures functioning to control the flow or raise the level of water. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: gaging stations
children.definition: Structures used to measure the condition of a hydrographic feature. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: harbors
children.definition: Sheltered areas of water where ships or other watercraft can anchor or dock. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: marinas
children.definition: Harbor facilities for recreational craft where supplies, repairs, and various services are available. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: levees
children.definition: Artificial embankments built along the bank of a watercourse or an arm of the sea, to protect land from inundation or to confine streamflow to its channel. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: offshore platforms
children.definition: Structures erected in a sea primarily, but not exclusively, for the extraction of petroleum products. [Adapted from USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: piers
children.definition: Structures used to protect a harbor or shore, and serving also as a promenade or as landing places for vessels. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: reservoirs
children.definition: Artificially impounded bodies of water. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: waterworks
children.definition: Water facilities, including tanks, buildings, pumps, and pipes, that process water for cities, towns, or other municipalities. [Adapted from American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: launch facilities
children.definition: Areas from which rockets/missiles may be housed and projected, usually equipped with associated buildings and facilities. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: mine sites
children.definition: Places or areas from which commercial minerals are or were removed by excavation from the Earth. [Adapted from USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: monuments
children.definition: Structures erected as memorials. [Adapted from American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: oil fields
children.definition: Areas with reserves of recoverable petroleum or where petroleum has been removed from the Earth.  [Adapted from USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: parks
children.definition: Places or areas developed for public use or recreation. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: amusement parks
children.definition: Commercially operated enterprises that offer rides, games, and other forms of entertainment. [American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: camps
children.definition: Designated areas on which primitive structure(s) are erected for temporary shelter or where recreational vehicles are temporarily parked. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: performance sites
children.definition: Buildings where cultural events are presented before an audience.

children.label: sports facilities
children.definition: Fields, centers, or open areas maintained for the purpose of holding sporting events and activities. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: paleontological sites
children.definition: Sites with notable fossil remains.

children.label: reserves
children.definition: Areas set aside for the preservation of fauna, flora, and their natural habitats. [Macmillan Encyc., 2001]

children.label: storage structures
children.definition: Large containers used for storage. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: towers
children.definition: Manmade structures, higher than their diameter, generally used for observation, storage, or electronic transmission. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: airport features
children.definition: Manmade facilities maintained for the use of aircraft. [USGS GNIS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: heliports
children.definition: Places for helicopters to land and take off. [American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: seaplane bases
children.definition: Installations supporting aircraft capable of taking off and landing on water. [NIMA Feature Attribute Coding Catalog (FACC)]

children.label: aqueducts
children.definition: Structures designed to transport water from a remote source, usually by gravity. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: bridges
children.definition: Structures erected over a depression or obstacle to carry traffic. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: cableways
children.definition: Conveyor systems in which carrier units run on wire cables strung between supports. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: locks
children.definition: Stretches of water in canals, streams, or docks, enclosed by gates at each end, and used in raising and lowering boats as they pass from one water level to another. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: parking sites
children.definition: Designated areas where motor vehicles are left temporarily. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: pipelines
children.definition: Tubular conduits of substantial length, with pumps, valves, and control devices, for conveying fluids, gases, or finely divided solids. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: roadways
children.definition: Open ways for passage of vehicles. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: trails
children.definition: Cleared paths, beaten tracks, or improved surfaces, as through woods or wilderness, not usually trafficked by vehicles because of width, seasonal conditions, or access restrictions. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: tunnels
children.definition: Underground or underwater passages. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: wells
children.definition: Manmade shafts or holes in the Earth's surface used to obtain fluid or gaseous materials. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: windmills
children.definition: Mills or other machines that run on the energy generated by a wheel of adjustable blades or flats rotated by the wind. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: alluvial fans
children.definition: Fan-shaped deposits of alluvium (river or stream-bed  sediment).

children.label: arroyos
children.definition: Small deep flat-floored channels or gullies of an ephemeral stream or of an intermittent stream, usually with vertical or steeply cut banks. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: badlands
children.definition: Areas characterized by a maze of very closely spaced, deep, narrow, steep-sided ravines, and sharp crests and pinnacles. [NIMA GEONet Designation ... Definitions <http://164.214.2.59/gns/html/desig.html> ]

children.label: banks (hydrographic)
children.definition: Sloping margins of, or the ground bordering, a stream, and serving to confine the water to the natural channel during the normal course of flow. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: bars (physiographic)
children.definition: Natural accumulations of sand, gravel, or other material forming an underwater or exposed embankment. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: basins
children.definition: Bowl-shaped, natural depressions in the surface of the land or ocean floor. [Adapted from USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: storage basins
children.definition: Basins in which drainage water is naturally detained. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: beaches
children.definition: Sloping shores along a body of water that is washed by waves or tides and is usually covered by sand or gravel. [USGS GNIS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: bights
children.definition: Long gradual bends or gentle curves, or slight crescent-shaped indentations, in the shoreline of an open coast or of a bay. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: capes
children.definition: Projection of land extending into a body of water that prominently marks a change in or interrupts the coastal trend of that water body. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: caves
children.definition: Natural underground passageways or chambers, or hollowed out cavities in the side of a cliff. [USGS GNIS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: cirques
children.definition: Bowl-like hollows partially surrounded by cliffs or steep slopes at the head of a glaciated valley. [NIMA GEONet Designation ... Definitions <http://164.214.2.59/gns/html/desig.html>]

children.label: cliffs
children.definition: High vertical, near-vertical, or overhanging faces of rock, earth, or ice. [USGS Circ. 1048]

children.label: craters
children.definition: Circular-shaped depressions at the summit of a volcanic core or on the surface of the land caused by the impact of a meteorite; man-made depressions caused by an explosion. [USGS GNIS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: deltas
children.definition: Flat plains formed by alluvial deposits at the mouth of a stream. [NIMA GEONet Designation ... Definitions <http://164.214.2.59/gns/html/desig.html>]

children.label: dunes
children.definition: Low mounds, ridges, banks, or hills of loose, wind-blown granular material, either bare or covered with vegetation, capable of movement from place to place but always retaining their characteristic shape. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: flats
children.definition: Relatively level areas within regions of greater relief. [USGS GNIS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: gaps
children.definition: Ravines or gorges cut deeply through mountain ridges, or between hills or mountains. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: isthmuses
children.definition: Narrow sections of land in a body of water connecting two larger land areas. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: karst areas
children.definition: Areas of geologic formations of irregular limestone deposits with sinks, underground streams, and caverns.  [EPA Terms of Environment < http://www.epa.gov/OCEPAterms/>]

children.label: ledges
children.definition: Narrow shelves or projections of rock formed on a rock wall or cliff face. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: massifs
children.definition: Massive topographic and structural features, commonly formed of rocks more rigid than those of their surroundings. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: mesas
children.definition: Very broad, flat-topped, usually isolated hills or mountains of moderate height bounded on at least one side by a steep cliff or slope and representing an erosion remnant. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: mineral deposit areas
children.definition: Areas where masses of naturally occurring mineral material are found, e.g. metal ores or nonmetallic minerals. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: moraines
children.definition: Accumulations of earth and stones carried and deposited by a glacier. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: mountains
children.definition: Landmasses that project conspicuously above their surroundings. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: continental divides
children.definition: Drainage divides that separate streams flowing towards opposite sides of a continent, often into different oceans. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: mountain ranges
children.definition: (a) Chains of hills or mountains; (b) somewhat linear, complex mountainous or hilly areas. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: mountain summits
children.definition: Peaks of mountains. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: ridges
children.definition: Elevations with a narrow, elongated crest which can be part of a hill or mountain. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: drumlins
children.definition: Low, smoothly rounded, elongate oval hills, mounds or ridges of compact glacial till built under the margin of the ice and shaped by its flow, or carved out of an older moraine by readvancing ice. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: natural rock formations
children.definition: Naturally formed topographic features, commonly differing conspicuously from adjacent objects or material. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: arches (natural formation)
children.definition: Natural arch-like openings in a rock mass. [USGS GNIS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: plains
children.definition: Regions of general uniform slope, comparatively level and of considerable extent. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: plateaus
children.definition: Comparatively flat areas of great extent and elevation; specif. extensive land regions considerably above the adjacent country or above sea level; commonly limited on at least one side by an abrupt descent, have flat or nearly smooth surfaces but are often dissected by deep valleys and surmounted by high hills or mountains, and have a large part of their total surface at or near the summit level. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: playas
children.definition: Closed depressions in an arid or semi-arid region that are periodically inundated by surface runoff, or the salt flat within such a closed basin.[Encyc. Dictionary of Physical Geography]

children.label: reefs
children.definition: Chains of rocks or coral at or near the surface of water. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: coral reefs
children.definition: Chains of coral at or near the surface. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: abyssal features
children.definition: Features on the ocean floor at a depth of 3500 - 6000 meters. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: continental margins
children.definition: Ocean floor between the shoreline and the abyssal ocean floor. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: fracture zones
children.definition: Elongated zones of unusually irregular topography on the deep-sea floor that often separate regions of different depths [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: hydrothermal vents
children.definition: Cracks along a rift or ridge in the deep ocean floor that spews out water heated to high temperature by the magma under the Earth's crust. [Columbia Electronic Encyc., 1999]

children.label: ocean trenches
children.definition: Narrow, elongate depressions of the deep-sea floor associated with a subduction zone. They are oriented parallel to volcanic arcs and commonly to the edge of the continent, between the continental margin and the abyssal hills. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: seamounts
children.definition: Elevations of the sea floor, 1000 m or higher, either flat-topped (guyots) or peaked (seapeaks). [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: submarine canyons
children.definition: Steep-sided, V-profile valley often heading in the continental shelf running down the continental slope, having tributaries and resembling unglaciated, river-cut land canyons. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: tectonic features
children.definition: Features resulting from structural deformation of the earth's crust through tectonic processes. [Adapted from American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: faults
children.definition: Fractures in the Earth's crust accompanied by a displacement of one side of the fracture with respect to the other. [UGSG Circ 1048]

children.label: fault zones
children.definition: Areas characterized by fractures in the Earth's crust. [Adapted from UGSG Circ 1048]

children.label: rift zones
children.definition: Divergent tectonic plate boundaries.

children.label: folds (geologic)
children.definition: Curves or bends of a planar structure such as rock strata, bedding planes, foliation or cleavage; usually products of deformation. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: anticlines
children.definition: Geologic folds in surface strata sloping downward on both sides from a common crest. [Adapted from American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: synclines
children.definition: Trough-shaped folds or downfolds in folded rock strata, the strata dipping towards a central axis.  [Macmillan Encyc., 2001]

children.label: subduction zones
children.definition: Convergent tectonic plate boundaries in which one plate is moving downward.

children.label: valleys
children.definition: Low-lying land bordered by higher ground; especially elongate, relatively large gently sloping depressions of the Earth's surface, commonly situated between two mountains or between ranges of hills or mountains, and often containing a stream with an outlet. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: canyons
children.definition: Relatively narrow, deep depressions with steep sides, the bottom of which generally has a continuous slope [NIMA GEONet Designation ... Definitions <http://164.214.2.59/gns/html/desig.html>]

children.label: volcanic features
children.definition: Features formed from those igneous rocks that have reached or nearly reached the Earth's surface before solidifying. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: lava fields
children.definition: Areas of formations resulting from the consolidation of molten rock on the surface of the Earth. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: volcanoes
children.definition: Vents in the surface of the Earth through which magma and associated gases erupt; also, the forms or structures, usually conical, that are produced by the erupted material. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: regions
children.definition: (a) Large, indefinite portions of the earth's surface. (b) Specified districts or territories. (c) Areas of interest or activity; spheres. (d) Ecology. Parts of the earth characterized by distinctive animal or plant life. [Adapted from American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: biogeographic regions
children.definition: Geographic regions characterized chiefly by the dominant forms of plant life and the prevailing climate. [Adapted from American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: barren lands
children.definition: Places composed of bare rock, sand, gravel, or other earthen material with little or no vegetation and having limited ability to support life. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: deserts
children.definition: Regions rendered barren or partially barren by environmental extremes, especially by low rainfall. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: forests
children.definition: Dense growths of trees, plants, and underbrush covering a large area. [American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: petrified forests
children.definition: Fossilized remains of large dense growths of trees. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: rain forests
children.definition: Forests where the annual rainfall is at least 100 inches. The regions are characterized by tall, lush, evergreen trees. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: woods
children.definition: Small areas covered with a dense growth of trees. [USGS Feature Class Definitions <http://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/feature_class.htm>]

children.label: grasslands
children.definition: Extensive noncultivated areas where vegetation is dominated by grasses or grass-like plants. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: habitats
children.definition: Particular environments or places where an organism or species tends to live. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: jungles
children.definition: Tropical regions of wild, tangled, dense vegetation. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: oases
children.definition: Fertile, vegetated areas in the midst of a desert, where the water table has come close enough to the surface for wells and springs or seepages to exist, thus making them suitable for human habitation. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: shrublands
children.definition: Areas covered with low-growing or stunted perennial vegetation and usually not mixed with trees. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: snow regions
children.definition: (a) Broad expanses of terrain covered with snow, relatively smooth and uniform in appearance, occurring usually at high latitudes or in mountainous regions above the snowline, and persisting throughout the year. (b) Regions of permanent snow cover, as at the heads of glaciers. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: tundras
children.definition: Treeless, level, or gently rolling plains characteristic of arctic or subarctic regions, having a permanently frozen subsoil, and usually supporting low growing vegetation such as lichens, mosses, and stunted shrubs. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: wetlands
children.definition: Vegetated areas that are inundated or saturated by surface or ground water for a significant part of the year. The vegetation is adapted for life in saturated soil conditions. [USGS Circ 1048]

children.label: climatic regions
children.definition: Regions whose ecologic formations result from or are influenced by differences in climate. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: coastal zones
children.definition: Strips of land (of indefinite width) that extend from the low-tide line inland to the first major change in landform features. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: land regions
children.definition: Use for land areas distinguished from ocean areas as well as general land-based regions without a more specific type designation.

children.label: continents
children.definition: Earth's major land masses, including both dry land and continental shelves. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: islands
children.definition: Tracts of land smaller than a continent, surrounded by the water of an ocean, sea, lake or stream. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: archipelagos
children.definition: Seas or areas in a sea that contain numerous islands; also, the island groups themselves. [Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: subcontinents
children.definition: (a) Divisions or parts of a continent having characteristics that distinguish them from the rest of the continent. These subdivision are typically based on geologic or geomorphic characteristics. (b) Large land masses smaller than any of the seven recognized continents. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]

children.label: UTM zones
children.definition: Gridded areas of the Earth's surface resulting from the use of the Universal Transverse Mercator projection and the international coding conventions for labeling the zones.

children.label: chart regions
children.definition: Map regions showing coastlines, water depths, or other information of use to navigators. [Adapted from American Heritage Dic. of the English Language, 4th ed.]

children.label: map quadrangle regions
children.definition: Regions on rectangular maps bounded by parallels of latitude and meridians of longitude, generally published in a series with prescribed scale. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]
